importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the previous longest government shutdown, which began on December 22, 2018, and lasted until January 25, 2019, making it the longest in history at 35 days.
The date of the latest update to the article, indicating ongoing relevance and current status of the government shutdown as of October 21, 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current government shutdown is ongoing as of the article's publication date, with no spending deal reached to reopen the federal government.
The previous longest government shutdown lasted 35 days, from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019, and is referenced as the longest in history.

keyTakeAways: The current government shutdown is a full shutdown, unlike the 2018 partial shutdown, because no of the 12 appropriations bills have been passed by Congress.
The last government shutdown (December 2018 to January 2019) lasted 35 days and was the longest in nearly 50 years, costing an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP.
The 1976 shutdown marked the first federal government shutdown, and since then, government shutdowns have become less frequent but have increased in duration due to partisan gridlock.
In recent decades, there have been six government shutdowns since 1990, indicating a growing trend of legislative deadlock.

The current shutdown is occurring under a Republican-led Congress with Speaker Mike Johnson, who oversees one of the narrowest House majorities in history, and without the 60 votes needed to overcome a Senate filibuster.

During the 2018 shutdown, about 300,000 federal employees were furloughed, and 800,000 were employed in shuttered agencies; both furloughed and exempted employees received backpay when operations resumed.
The United States federal government remains shut down as of the article's publication date due to an unresolved spending deal on Capitol Hill.

namedEntities.name: United States federal government
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The central government of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The subject of the shutdown, with operations halted due to lack of funding.

namedEntities.name: Capitol Hill
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative district where Congress meets
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location where Congress failed to pass funding bills, leading to the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nonpartisan agency that provides economic and fiscal analysis
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Credited with estimating the $3 billion GDP loss from the 2018 shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican Speaker of the House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He oversees a narrow House majority and is a key political figure during the current legislative impasse.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A procedural rule allowing extended debate to block legislation
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The GOP lacks the 60 votes needed to end a filibuster, making it difficult to pass funding bills.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provides reporting on which government services are affected during the shutdown.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Year of the first federal government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Marks the beginning of documented government shutdowns in U.S. history.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Year when federal agencies began being instructed to stop operations during funding lapses
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Establishes a policy framework for how shutdowns were initially managed.

namedEntities.name: December 22, 2018
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Start date of the last major shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The beginning of the 35-day shutdown, which remains the longest in history.

namedEntities.name: January 25, 2019
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: End date of the last major shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The conclusion of the 35-day shutdown, marking the end of the longest in history.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The United States federal government is currently in a full shutdown due to Congress failing to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills, marking a significant and ongoing disruption. This follows the previous longest government shutdown in history—lasting 35 days from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019—which cost an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP and resulted in approximately 300,000 federal employees being furloughed. The article highlights that while government shutdowns have decreased in frequency since the 1980s, political gridlock, particularly in Congress with narrow majorities and a lack of votes to overcome a Senate filibuster, has made resolving funding disputes increasingly difficult. Speaker Mike Johnson leads a Republican-controlled House with one of the narrowest majorities, contributing to the current stalemate. The situation underscores broader concerns about partisan division and the long-term effects of legislative deadlock on public services and the economy.
title: The US government remains shut down with a spending deal still out of reach — here's how long the current shutdown has been going on
